acide.ui.surface module#

surface module.

To allow using of GTK on screens with very high DPI value GTK3 and GTK4 use logical pixels, as opposed to physical ones. This is, the user can configure the desktop environment to scale the pixel size, generally by factor 1 for ordinary displays and by 2 for high DPI displays. So on a HiDPI display the logical and physical measurements may differ in scale, typically by a factor of 2. In most places we’re dealing with logical units methods, but take care that some methods like Texture.get_width() returns physical units.

do_get_request_mode()[source]#

Gets whether the widget prefers a height-for-width layout or a width-for-height layout.

Single-child widgets generally propagate the preference of their child, more complex widgets need to request something either in context of their children or in context of their allocation capabilities.

Return type:

SizeRequestMode

do_measure(orientation, for_size)[source]#

Measures widget for the orientation and for the given for_size.

As an example, if orientation is GTK_ORIENTATION_HORIZONTAL and for_size is 300, this functions will compute the minimum and natural width of widget if it is allocated at a height of 300 pixels. Return measurements are in logical pixel unit within a tuple (int minimum, int natural, int minimum_baseline, int natural_baseline).

Parameters:

  • for_size (int) –

update_metrics()[source]#

Update internal matrix.

Update all internel matrix and transformation coefficients used for rendering. This is usually called when properties like dpi or size for this viewport changed or when a Graphic is added. It is safe to called update_metrics() at any time when needed.

update_monitor_infos(caller=None)[source]#

Update infos for monitor displaying self.

This function can only be called after the widget has been added to a widget hierarchy with a GtkWindow at the top. In general, we should only create display specific resources when a widget has been realized.
